name: Progressive Necrotizing Fasciitis with Cutaneous Gangrene
chief_complaint: Severe pain and blackening skin on my left forearm that's spreading rapidly
symptoms: excruciating localized pain disproportionate to visible injury
physical_findings: crepitus on palpation of affected area
demarcated necrotic tissue with violaceous margins
positive 'finger test' (easy separation of fascial planes)

lab_results.Blood Culture: Gram-positive cocci in chains (presumptive Streptococcus pyogenes)

treatment: emergent radical surgical debridement with 2cm margins
quadruple IV antibiotics (vancomycin, clindamycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, gentamicin)
future reconstructive surgery with free flap transfer
prognosis: Guarded - mortality rate 25-35% even with treatment; significant functional impairment likely
description: Life-threatening polymicrobial necrotizing soft tissue infection involving superficial fascia, deep fascia, and surrounding tissues. Characterized by rapid tissue destruction (2-3cm/hour progression) due to bacterial exotoxins and impaired microcirculation. Requires immediate surgical intervention to prevent septic shock.
risk_factors: recent puncture wound (patient is a fisherman)
